benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/export/{accountId} - Export account data

covered: Valid Request: Successful export scenarios are covered (TC01, TC02, TC14, TC15) asserting 200 responses and Content-Type application/octet-stream.
Header handling: Required header presence and missing required header behavior covered; optional headers, extra/legacy headers and unsupported headers are tested (TC01-TC03, TC06, TC15).
Path parameter validation: Malformed UUID and injection/malicious inputs are tested producing 400 responses (TC04, TC11).
Not found / Empty DB: Non-existent account and empty database scenarios return 404 as expected (TC05, TC07).
Error and resiliency scenarios: Service-unavailable (500), long-running/timeouts (504), slow downstream and performance/large-export checks are present (TC08-TC10, TC17).
Concurrency and method handling: Concurrent requests behavior and unsupported HTTP method (405) are tested (TC13, TC16).
Authentication existence: Missing/invalid auth token scenario covered returning 401 (TC18).
Response body as binary stream: Tests assert response is an octet-stream and validate a "valid export archive" and size thresholds for large exports (TC01, TC02, TC08).
Documentation/accessibility: API documentation discoverability and accessibility are included (TC19).
gaps: Authorization scope and permissions (403): No tests for authenticated users lacking permission to export another account or for token-scoped/role-based denial (403) and ownership constraints.

Content integrity and semantics: No tests verify that the returned archive actually contains the expected account data (file list, record contents), or validate checksums, archive format specifics (zip/tar/gz) and file naming.
Caching behavior: No tests for ETag, Cache-Control, Last-Modified or conditional GET behavior (If-None-Match -> 304).
Rate limiting / throttling: No tests exercising rate limits or 429 Retry-After behavior; TC13 concurrency partially covers concurrency but not throttling policies.
Partial content, HEAD and streaming behavior: No tests for HEAD support, Range requests (206 partial content), Transfer-Encoding chunked vs Content-Length, or resumable downloads for large exports.
Header value validation and edge cases: No tests for empty, oversized, or otherwise invalid header values (e.g., X-Killbill-CreatedBy length/characters).
Authentication variants and token cases: No tests for expired/invalid tokens, different auth mechanisms or distinction between 401 vs 403 in nuanced auth failures.
Accept header negotiation and content-encoding/metadata: No tests for Accept header handling, Content-Encoding, or Content-Disposition (attachment filename) and related metadata.
Pagination: Not applicable for single-account export endpoint (no pagination expected) so it is not exercised.
recommendations: Add authorization/permission tests that assert 403 for authenticated users without rights to export the target account; include token-scope and ownership tests.
Add content-level verification: decompress the returned archive and assert expected files, entity counts, sample record contents, checksums and archive format (zip/tar/gz).
Add caching tests: verify presence of ETag/Cache-Control/Last-Modified and conditional GET behavior (If-None-Match -> expect 304 when unchanged).
Add rate-limiting and throttling tests: flood the endpoint to validate 429 responses, Retry-After behavior and graceful degradation under high request rates.
Add streaming and partial-download tests: validate HEAD responses, Range requests (206), Content-Length vs chunked Transfer-Encoding, and resumable download behavior for large exports.
Add header edge-case tests: empty, very long or malformed X-Killbill-CreatedBy and other header values to ensure proper 4xx validation.
Add authentication variant tests: expired tokens, malformed tokens, and differently scoped tokens to confirm correct 401/403 handling and audit logging.
Add tests for Accept negotiation and metadata headers: Content-Encoding, Content-Disposition filename and Content-Length to help clients consume the export correctly.
Expand performance/load testing beyond a single concurrency scenario to validate throughput, timeouts, and interactions with rate limiting under production-like load.
